Mercedes-Benz

By Drew Dorian

Overview

It looks like a regular GLC-class, but the electric powertrain hiding under the sheetmetal sets the 2026 Mercedes-Benz GLC-class EV on an entirely different journey. We’ve had a chance to test drive a prototype of the new compact electric crossover on frozen roads in northern Sweden, and its ride is smooth, its powertrain is perky, and its luxury experience is well intact. We don’t have all the info yet, but the dual-motor all-wheel-drive version we sampled has an estimated 483 horsepower and uses a large battery pack with at least 300 miles of driving range. More details about the GLC-Class EV will drop closer to the SUV’s launch; it officially debuts in September 2025 at the Munich IAA auto show. When the GLC EV goes on sale, it will compete with the upcoming BMW iX3, the Porsche Macan EV, and the Polestar 3.

What's New for 2026?

The GLC-Class EV will be a new addition to the Mercedes-Benz lineup when it debuts, likely as a 2026 model. It will slot in under the mid-size EQE SUV and its naming convention marks a move away from the EQ prefix that Benz has used on its EVs so far.

Pricing and Which One to Buy

The price of the 2027 Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class EV is expected to start around $65,000 and go up to $70,000 depending on the trim and options.

Mercedes-Benz hasn’t released pricing or trim-level information for the GLC-Class EV yet, but we think it will pick up where the GLC350e hybrid leaves off, with a base price of around $65,000. When we learn more about the GLC EV’s price and features, we’ll update this story with details.

EV Motor, Power, and Performance

While it’s possible we will get a single-motor rear- or front-wheel-drive variant here as well, we’ve only driven the dual-motor all-wheel-drive variant so far. Our prototype test car was said to have about 483 horsepower on tap, which proved to be plenty to move the GLC-Class EV around on wintry Swedish roads. A two-speed automatic transmission is onboard, but you don’t really feel it shifting gears. Ride comfort is good, especially on the optional air-spring suspension system, which can also raise the GLC EV up for more ground clearance should you decide to venture off-road.

Range, Charging, and Battery Life

The GLC-Class EV houses a 94.5-kWh battery pack under its floorboards, which will likely be enough for an EPA-estimated driving range of over 300 miles. Charging at a DC fast-charging station should be brisk, as the battery can accept charging rates as high as 320 kilowatts.

Warranty and Maintenance Coverage

Mercedes-Benz provides competitive warranty coverage compared with premium rivals. However, the German automaker doesn't offer the complimentary maintenance that BMW and Jaguar do.

  • Limited warranty covers four years or 50,000 miles
  • Powertrain warranty covers four years or 50,000 miles
  • Battery components are covered for eight years or 100,000 miles
  • No complimentary scheduled maintenance

As more information becomes available, we'll update this story with more details about:
